    Ward:All 
    Request to maintain Canada Post Services - by Councillor Michelle Berardinetti, seconded by Councillor Peter Leon
    * Notice of this Motion has been given.
    * This Motion is subject to referral to the Executive Committee. A two-thirds vote is required to waive referral.
    Recommendations

    Councillor Michelle Berardinetti, seconded by Councillor Peter Leon, recommends that:

     

    1.         City Council request the City Manager to convey to the Federal Minister responsible for Canada Post, the Honourable Lisa Raitt, that the Federal Government should direct Canada Post to maintain the current system of residential door-to-door delivery in Canada. 
    Summary

    The City of Toronto and its residents have a direct financial and personal interest in the security and stability of Canada's postal system.  Canada Post's recent announcement concerning a proposed reduction in mail services is unprecedented among major industrialized nations and the decision making process by Canada Post was absent any reasonable effort to consult with stakeholders and those most affected by the changes.

     

    (Submitted to City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014 as MM48.8)
    Background Information
    Member Motion MM48.8
    (http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-66914.pdf)

    Notice of Motion
    MM48.9

    ACTION 

     

     

    Ward:All 
    "In Service" Maintaining Charitable and Community Services when Churches are Sold - by Councillor Paula Fletcher, seconded by Councillor Joe Mihevc
    * Notice of this Motion has been given.
    * This Motion is subject to referral to the Community Development and Recreation Committee. A two-thirds vote is required to waive referral.
    Recommendations

    Councillor Paula Fletcher, seconded by Councillor Joe Mihevc, recommends that:

     

    1.         City Council request the Deputy City Manager, Cluster A, to create an inventory of facilities and programs funded by the City located in churches across Toronto.

     

    2.         City Council request the Deputy City Manager, Cluster A, to report to the June 25, 2014 meeting of the Community Development and Recreation Committee with options for maintaining charitable and community services in their existing locations when a church is sold.
    Summary

    Across the City, churches have traditionally played a vital role in our communities by providing social programs and services for those in need.  The network of services include child care facilities, parent-child resource centres, affordable housing units, meal and shelter programs, and other community supports.  Quite often these services receive funding through the City.

     

    Many churches are now being put up for sale, and unfortunately there are no provisions to consider the social services the community relies on and ensure they are maintained after the sale.  The loss of these services puts additional strain on City resources and can come as a surprise to those who rely on the services in their daily lives.

     

    (Submitted to City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014 as MM48.9)
    Background Information
    Revised Member Motion MM48.9
    (http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-66915.pdf)

    Notice of Motion
    MM48.10

    ACTION 

     

     

    Ward:All 
    Extension of Alcohol Sales and Service Hours During the 2014 Winter Olympics - by Councillor Mike Layton, seconded by Councillor Michael Thompson
    * Notice of this Motion has been given.
    * This Motion is subject to referral to the Economic Development Committee. A two-thirds vote is required to waive referral.
    * This Motion has been deemed urgent.

    The General Manager, Economic Development and Culture has submitted a supplementary report on this Item (MM48.10a for information)

    Bill 108 has been submitted on this Item.
    Recommendations

    Councillor Mike Layton, seconded by Councillor Michael Thompson, recommends that:

     

    1.         City Council authorize the extension of alcohol sales and service hours in the City of Toronto, in areas other than the Wards identified in Recommendation 2, to begin at 6:00 a.m. between February 20 and February 23, 2014 to allow local cafes and restaurants to take advantage of the economic opportunities of this major international event.

     

    2.               City Council, at the request of the associated local Ward Councillors, not include the following Wards as part of the extension of alcohol sales and service hours in the City of Toronto:

     

                 -          Ward 9 - York Centre

                 -          Ward 24 - Willowdale

     

    3.               City Council authorize the City Solicitor to introduce a by-law substantially as set out in Appendix 1 to this Motion.
    Summary

    The 2014 Winter Olympics takes place between February 7 and 23, 2014 in Sochi, Russia - an event which Torontonians look forward to with a great deal of enthusiasm and celebrate with a tremendous amount of good will.

     

    As with many major international sporting events, the XXII Olympic Winter Games represent an opportunity for residents to come together to celebrate and cheer for their country. As such, the Games also represent and opportunity for small businesses to host these celebrations.

     

    The time difference between Toronto and Sochi has resulted in unusual match times. In particular, the men's and women's medal hockey games will air as early as at 7:00 a.m. local time, between February 20 and 23, 2014. As a result, residents may wish to patronize local cafes and restaurants earlier than normal during this specific time period.

     

    The ability to serve alcohol earlier than the provincial standard would allow business operators to benefit more from the celebratory participation of many Torontonians and visitors to the City. Under the Liquor Licence Act, the City may itself pass a by-law extending the hours of sale in all or a part of the City by holders of licences under the Act. 

     

    (Submitted to City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014 as MM48.10)
    Background Information
    Member Motion MM48.10
    (http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-66916.pdf)
    Appendix 1 - Draft By-law
    (http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-66921.pdf)
    (February 17, 2014) Supplementary Report from the General Manager, Economic Development and Culture on Extension of Alcohol Sales and Service Hours During the 2014 Winter Olympics (MM48.10a)
    (http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67034.pdf)

    Notice of Motion
    MM48.11

    ACTION 

     

     

    Ward:19 
    Liquor Licence Application for Increased Capacity - 2270121 Ontario Inc. operating as Church Aperitivo Bar, 1090 Queen Street West, - Licence Number 814239 - by Councillor Mike Layton, seconded by Councillor Gord Perks
    * Notice of this Motion has been given.
    * This Motion is subject to referral to the Toronto and East York Community Council. A two-thirds vote is required to waive referral.
    * This Motion relates to an Alcohol and Gaming Commission of Ontario Hearing and has been deemed urgent.
    Recommendations

    Councillor Mike Layton, seconded by Councillor Gord Perks, recommends that:

     

    1.         City Council direct the City Clerk to advise the Registrar of the Alcohol and Gaming Commission of Ontario (“AGCO”) that the liquor licence expansion application for Church Aperitivo, 1090 Queen Street West (the “Premises”), is not in the public interest having regard to the needs and wishes of the residents, and that the Registrar should issue a Proposal to Review the liquor licence expansion application.

     

    2.         City Council request the AGCO and the Licence Appeal Tribunal (“LAT”) to provide the City of Toronto with an opportunity to participate in any additional proceedings with respect to the Premises.

     

    3.         City Council authorize the City Solicitor to attend all proceedings before the AGCO and the LAT in this matter and direct the City Solicitor to take all necessary actions so as to give effect to this Motion, including adding and deleting conditions to the current liquor licence issued for the Premises in consultation with the Ward Councillor, which address issues including, but not limited to, noise, safety, security personnel, security cameras, crowd control, signage, lighting and litter.
    Summary

    2270121 Ontario Inc. has applied to the Alcohol and Gaming Commission of Ontario (AGCO) to increase the indoor area capacity of their liquor licence at Church Aperitivo Bar, 1090 Queen Street West (the “Premises”). The applicant is seeking an increase from 99 patrons to 180 patrons.

     

    The City objects to the application for increased capacity.  Currently, the City is objecting to an application to remove two conditions from the Premises’ liquor licence (one related to noise impacts) and a hearing has been scheduled for April 23 to 25, 2014.  A prosecution under the City’s noise by-law is also currently in front of the Courts.  Until such time that appropriate noise mitigation measures have been implemented at the Premises to prevent impacts on neighbouring residents, it is premature to have the capacity for the Premises increased.  Even if appropriate noise mitigation measures are in place, this application for an expansion of capacity is not in the public interest given the size of the proposed increase from 99 patrons to 180 patrons, unless certain conditions, addressing the concerns of the community, are attached to the licence.  Under no circumstance should the expansion application be granted without additional conditions being attached to the licence.

     

    This matter is considered urgent as the deadline for submissions to the AGCO to object to the expansion application is March 2, 2014.

     

    (Submitted to Council on February 19 and 20, 2014 as MM48.11)
    Background Information
    Member Motion MM48.11
    (http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-66918.pdf)

    Notice of Motion
    MM48.12

    ACTION 

     

     

    Ward:All 
    Providing Authority for Staff to Take the Next Steps in the process to designate Public Lands along the Humber and Don River Valleys and the Etobicoke Creek as part of the Greenbelt - by Councillor Glenn De Baeremaeker, seconded by Councillor Maria Augimeri
    * Notice of this Motion has been given.
    * This Motion is subject to referral to the Planning and Growth Management Committee. A two-thirds vote is required to waive referral.
    Recommendations

    Councillor Glenn De Baeremaeker, seconded by Councillor Maria Augimeri, recommends that:

     

    1.         City Council direct the Chief Planner and Executive Director, City Planning in conjunction with the appropriate City staff to begin the process of making an application to the Province for Urban River Valley designation for public lands in the Humber and Don River Valleys and Etobicoke Creek. Specifically, City staff shall:

     

                a.         initiate coordination with other public landowners to identify lands suitable for Urban River Valley designation;

     

                 b.        develop a cost estimation for the Urban River Valley designation;

     

                c.         work with the Province of Ontario to agree on the scope and extent of public consultation required before proceeding;

     

                 d.        work with the Province of Ontario on ways in which the Greenbelt Plan can be improved to better assist municipalities with Urban River Valley-designated lands in necessary restoration and stewardship actions; and

     

                e.         report back to the Planning and Growth Management Committee by May 2014 with a plan and cost estimates to expand the Provincial Greenbelt by designating selected public lands as Urban River Valley, as outlined in Provincial legislation.
    Summary

    To help celebrate the 9th anniversary of the Greenbelt, this Motion would provide Council authority to continue the process of designating publicly owned lands along the Humber and Don River Valleys and the Etobicoke Creek as part of the Greenbelt.

     

    In February 2010, City Council adopted motions supporting, in principle, adding the Don and Humber River Valleys to the Greenbelt and calling on City staff to work with the Toronto and Region Conservation Authority, and report back to the Planning and Growth Management Committee about how to proceed (PE28.1).

     

    An April 13, 2011 staff report noted that there was no existing mechanism for Toronto to add these lands to the Greenbelt; and City Council requested “the Minister of Municipal Affairs and Housing to revise the Provincial Greenbelt Plan policies, as part of the 10 year review of Greenbelt Plan policy that will take place in 2015, in order to clarify how they should apply to external river valley connections and the role that municipalities can play in protecting these important connections between the Greenbelt and Lake Ontario.” (PG3.1)

     

    In January 2013, the Province amended the Greenbelt Plan through regulation and put in place a mechanism called the Urban River Valleys (URV) designation that allows publicly owned urban river valleys to be added to the Greenbelt by way of municipal request.

     

    The City of Mississauga also supported, in principle, growing the Greenbelt into URV lands, including URV lands on the west side of the Etobicoke Creek, and carried out an extensive feasibility study that was completed in November 2013.

     

    A January 2014 staff report from the City of Mississauga on growing the greenbelt into URVs in Mississauga determined that “[t]he benefits for designation include raising awareness of the role of the urban river valleys in supporting connection to a larger, regional natural heritage system; reinforcing land securement undertakings; and creating restoration, educational and stewardship opportunities. Expanding the Greenbelt locally would raise the profile of these valley lands through their inclusion in a Provincial plan that has a strong symbolic value and is expected to provide widespread positive recognition and support.”

     

    The same staff report also noted that “[s]taff support pursuing designation of suitable public lands along the Credit River and Etobicoke Creek as URV lands for the reasons outlined in the Feasibility Analysis, and recommend beginning preliminary work required (including costing), to pursue application for such designation through the Region.”

     

    On February 12, 2014, the City of Mississauga City Council considered the following staff recommendation: “That the Commissioner of Community Services be directed to submit a Corporate Report prior to the Summer 2014 Council recess, outlining a plan and cost estimates to expand the Provincial Greenbelt by designating selected public lands as Urban River Valley, as outlined in the Legislation.”

     

    (Submitted to City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014 as MM48.12)
    Background Information
    Member Motion MM48.12
    (http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-66917.pdf)

    Notice of Motion
    MM48.13

    ACTION 

     

     

    Ward:19 
    Liquor Licence - 1087-1089 Queen Street West - The Great Hall - AGCO File No. 812306 - by Councillor Mike Layton, seconded by Councillor Adam Vaughan
    * Notice of this Motion has been given.
    * This Motion is subject to referral to the Toronto and East York Community Council. A two-thirds vote is required to waive referral.
    * This Motion relates to an Alcohol and Gaming Commission of Ontario Hearing and has been deemed urgent.
    Recommendations

    Councillor Mike Layton, seconded by Councillor Adam Vaughan, recommends that:

     

    1.         City Council direct the City Clerk to advise the Registrar of the Alcohol and Gaming Commission of Ontario (“AGCO”) that the liquor licence application for The Great Hall, 1087-1089 Queen Street West (the “Premises”), is not in the public interest having regard to the needs and wishes of the residents, and that the Registrar should issue a Proposal to Review the liquor licence application.

               

    2.         City Council request the Licence Appeal Tribunal (“LAT”) to provide the City with an opportunity to be made a party in any proceedings with respect to the Premises.

     

    3.         City Council authorize the City Solicitor to attend all proceedings before the LAT in this matter and direct the City Solicitor to take all necessary actions so as to give effect to this Motion, including adding and deleting conditions to any liquor licence issued for the Premises, in consultation with the Ward Councillor, which address issues including, but not limited to, noise, safety, security personnel, security cameras, crowd control, signage, lighting and litter.
    Summary

    A.C. Great Hall Management Inc. has submitted an application for a liquor licence to the Alcohol and Gaming Commission of Ontario (“AGCO”) for a premises at 1087-1089 Queen Street West operating under the name The Great Hall (the “Premises”). The application is for an increase to the existing indoor capacity from about 303 to about 1,461 persons.

     

    The Premises is located in close proximity to residential properties in an area with a large concentration of licenced establishments. There is concern in the community that this very significant increase in capacity will lead to noise and other disturbances to residents in the area. The Premises already has certain conditions attached to its licence, related mostly to the mitigation of noise and other neighbourhood disturbances. Further conditions including but not limited to noise, safety, security personnel, security cameras, crowd control, signage, and lighting may be necessary in light of the increase in capacity.  As such, this application for a liquor licence is not in the public interest unless certain conditions, addressing the concerns of the community, are attached to the licence.

     

    (Submitted to City Council on February 19 and 20 as MM48.13)
    Background Information
    Member Motion MM48.13
    (http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-66919.pdf)

    Notice of Motion
    MM48.14

    ACTION 

     

     

    Ward:All 
    Declaration of Hispanic Heritage Month for the month of October - by Councillor Cesar Palacio, seconded by Deputy Mayor Norm Kelly
    * Notice of this Motion has been given.
    * This Motion is subject to referral to the Economic Development Committee. A two-thirds vote is required to waive referral.
    Communication MM48.14.1 has been submitted on this Item
    Recommendations

    Councillor Cesar Palacio, seconded by Deputy Mayor Norm Kelly, recommends that:

     

    1.         Toronto City Council formally declare October as "Hispanic Heritage Month" for the entire City in 2014, and for future years.

     

    2.         Toronto City Council formally request the Province of Ontario to declare October as "Hispanic Heritage Month" for the entire Province in 2014, and for future years.

     

    3.         Toronto City Council formally request the Government of Canada to declare October as “Hispanic Heritage Month” for the entire Country in 2014, and for future years.
    Summary

    The Canadian Hispanic population in Toronto is among the fastest growing ethnic groups in the City, representing over twenty Spanish speaking countries in the world. Several ethnic groups are recognized by the City annually with their own Heritage or Cultural Month including South Asian Heritage Month, Black History Month, Irish Heritage and Cultural Appreciation Month, and Portuguese Month.

     

    In 2009, Toronto City Council proclaimed April as "Hispanic Heritage Month", an action which has helped to commemorate and reinforce Canadian Hispanic culture in our City. As a result, several annual local events have taken place throughout Toronto and the Province of Ontario in recognition of the social, cultural and economic contribution of our Hispanic community. Furthermore, the City of Toronto has a formal Friendship Agreement with the City of Quito, Ecuador, and this proclamation has helped to keep with that agreement. Despite the successes that have been attained in the past through this noble effort, shifting this celebration to October will expand and strengthen "Hispanic Heritage Month" for 2014 and the future to come.

     

    "Hispanic Heritage Month" is celebrated in October throughout the world as Month of the Race. October is a month that strongly symbolizes and celebrates the Hispanic heritage by encouraging and promoting all its traditions, cultural influences and enriching ethnicity of all Latin roots throughout North, Central and South America and Spain.

     

    By declaring the celebration in autumn, the City, the Province, community organizations, institutions and the general consulates will be able to coordinate its efforts with the rest of the world in achieving top-tier cultural events that can attract visitors, stimulate our local economy, and reinforce our Hispanic roots. Furthermore, as all the Hispanic independence festivities conclude by the month of September, the idea of changing it to October will be represented as a closing ceremony for all the Hispanic Independence Days worldwide.

     

    Overall, the Hispanic Heritage Month working group has proposed to host large-scale events, including a Hispanic film festival, art festival, gastronomic festival, multicultural festival and an award recognition festival. Proclaiming October as "Hispanic Heritage Month" will give Canadian Hispanics, Torontonians, Ontarians and Canadians as a whole an opportunity to celebrate, enjoy and experience the rich heritage of Canada's Hispanic cultures. It will also provide our City with an opportunity to reflect on the many outstanding contributions Hispanics have made to Canadian society.

     

    The concept of a Hispanic Heritage Month, and moving the celebration from April to October, is supported in principle by the Hispanic Development Council, Centre for Spanish-Speaking Peoples, Canadian Hispanic Congress, Toronto District School Boards, Hispanic Fiesta Celebration, Las Flores Charitable Foundation, the Association of Ecuadorians in Ontario, Cultural Celebration of the Spanish Language, and a large number of Hispanic community leaders and community organizations.

     

    I am confident that this change in date will help to strengthen our collective efforts to celebrate Hispanic culture in our City, Province, Country, and abroad.

     

    (Submitted to City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014 as Member Motion MM48.14)
    Background Information
    Member Motion MM48.14
    (http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-66953.pdf)
    Letters in support of Hispanic Heritage Month, from Claudio Ruiz-Pilarte, The Centre for Spanish-Speaking People; Nuria L. Rajo, Canadian Hispanic Congress; Fernando Valladares, Hispanic Fiesta; Fernando Valladares, Las Flores Non-Profit Housing Corporation; Margarita Feliciano, Cultural Celebration of the Spanish Language; Jorge Patricio Viera, Association of Ecuadorians in Ontario; and Eduardo Harari, Hispanic Political Affairs Committee of Canada
    (http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-66956.pdf)
    Communications
    (February 20, 2014) Submission from Councillor Cesar Palacio, Ward 17 Davenport - Revised Motion Summary and additional letter of support from Duberlis Ramos on behalf of the Hispanic Canadian Heritage Council (MM.New.MM48.14.1)
    (http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/comm/communicationfile-45541.pdf)

    Notice of Motion
    MM48.15

    Ward:10 
    Authorization to Release Section 37 Funds from 929-939 Sheppard Avenue West for a Commemorative Heritage Plaque in Earl Bales Park - by Councillor James Pasternak, seconded by Councillor Peter Leon
    * Notice of this Motion has been given.

    Recommendations

    Councillor James Pasternak, seconded by Councillor Peter Leon, recommends that:

     

    1.         City Council increase the approved 2014 Operating Budget for Heritage Toronto by $4,500.00 gross, $0 net, fully funded by Section 37 community benefits secured in the development at 929-939 Sheppard Avenue West, (source account XR3026-3700124) for a heritage plaque commemorating the history of the John Bales House in Earl Bales Park.

    Section 37 funds have been secured and received in connection with the rezoning of By-law 1142-2004(OMB) for improvements to community facilities in Ward 10.

     

    In 2013, the North York Historical Society submitted an application to Heritage Toronto for a plaque to commemorate the history of John Bales House, which is situated in Earl Bales Park. Partial funding of $1,000 was secured in that application.  The cost of the plaque is $5,500.

     

    The balance of $4,500 will be funded through the Section 37 funds.

     

    (Submitted to City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014 as MM48.15)

    Notice of Motion
    MM48.16

    ACTION 

     

     

    Ward:All 
    Retrofitting Seniors Homes with Automatic Sprinkler Systems - by Councillor Joe Mihevc, seconded by Councillor Glenn De Baeremaeker
    * Notice of this Motion has been given.
    * This Motion is subject to referral to the Executive Committee. A two-thirds vote is required to waive referral.
    Recommendations

    Councillor Joe Mihevc, seconded by Councillor Glenn De Baeremaeker, recommends that:

     

    1.         City Council request the City Manager to write to the Premier of Ontario and the Minister of Municipal Affairs and Housing, and request that the Province expedite the timelines for retrofits to require sprinklers; and that the Province consider a low interest loan program to encourage faster retrofits of multi-residential buildings to include automatic sprinklers.
    Summary

    The recent fire at a seniors home in L'Isle Verte, Quebec shows the urgency of retrofitting seniors homes and other multi-unit residential buildings with automatic sprinkler systems.


    There have been 45 fire-related deaths in buildings which house seniors in Ontario since 1990. Many residents of seniors residences and their families, as well as leading fire and safety advocates across the country, have spoken about the urgent safety issue posed by the lack of sprinklers in many seniors facilities across the country.

     

    Toronto Fire Services has been active in conducting studies involving mock fire drills throughout senior homes in the City. They have demonstrated that sprinkler systems are crucial in saving lives, especially in seniors housing where evacuation times are relatively slower.

     

    The Ontario Building Code does not require the retrofit of all seniors homes with automatic sprinklers until as late as 2025.

     

    One reason commonly cited for the long timeline to retrofit buildings is the cost. These costs could be mitigated by a program to provide low interest loans to expedite the renovations. In addition to promoting public safety, this would have the added benefit of stimulating the economy and creating jobs in the construction industry and skilled trades.

     

    (Submitted to City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014 as MM48.16)
    Background Information
    Member Motion MM48.16
    (http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-66954.pdf)

    Notice of Motion
    MM48.17

    ACTION 

     

     

    Ward:All 
    Commemorating the 100th Anniversary of the Battle of Vimy Ridge - by Councillor James Pasternak, seconded by Councillor Josh Matlow
    * Notice of this Motion has been given.
    * This Motion is subject to referral to the Economic Development Committee. A two-thirds vote is required to waive referral.
    Recommendations

    Councillor James Pasternak, seconded by Councillor Josh Matlow, recommends that:

     

    1.         The City Manager, in conjunction with the City Clerk, report back to City Council on a strategy such that:

     

    a.         Toronto can host events during the week of April 9, 2017 across the City to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the Battle of Vimy Ridge. Events could include but not be limited to ceremonies in Civic Centres, community centres and at war memorials;

     

    b.         a strategic working group be assembled that would include veterans groups, families of Canadian World War I soldiers and community partners to play a leadership role in this endeavour; and

     

    c.         any plan moving forward includes intergovernmental coordination with federal and provincial counterparts.
    Summary

    The Battle of Vimy Ridge occurred from April 9 to 12, 1917 during World War I in Northern France. The battle is a historic moment for Canada where the country emerged from the shadow of Britain and our soldiers earned the reputation as a formidable force because of their stunning success at Vimy Ridge. This victory came at a terrible cost though with more than 10,000 killed and wounded.

     

    The Canadian Corps was ordered to seize Vimy Ridge in April 1917 after previous French Attacks had failed. It was a daunting task as the heavily-fortified seven-kilometre ridge held a commanding view over the Allied lines that had already seen over 100,000 causalities.

    The capture of Vimy also marked the first time all four Canadian divisions attacked together with soldiers from all regions of Canada present at the battle.

     

    With the passing of the Canadian men and women who served in the First World War, the responsibility falls upon us all to tell their stories and to share their achievements with each new generation of Canadians.

     

    (Submitted to City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014 as MM48.17)

     
    Background Information
    Member Motion MM48.17
    (http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-66955.pdf)

    Notice of Motion

    2014 Agnes Macphail Award Recipient - by Councillor Janet Davis, seconded by Councillor Mary Fragedakis

    The Agnes Macphail Award was established by the Borough of East York.  It continues today as an annual event to recognize an outstanding volunteer who lives within the boundaries of the former Borough.  The Agnes Macphail Selection Committee met, as established in the selection process, on February 10, 2014 to examine the nominations received and selected Sheila Lacroix as the recipient of the 2014 Agnes Macphail Award.  The award will be presented on March 24, 2014 which is the anniversary of Agnes Macphail's birth.

    Notice of Motion
    MM48.19

    ACTION 

     

     

    Ward:All 
    Protecting Toronto's Tenants: Above the Guideline Rent Increase Reform - by Councillor Josh Matlow, seconded by Councillor John Parker
    * Notice of this Motion has been given.
    * This Motion is subject to referral to the Executive Committee. A two-thirds vote is required to waive referral.
    Recommendations

    Councillor Josh Matlow, seconded by Councillor John Parker recommends that:

     

    1.         City Council request the Province of Ontario to amend section 126 of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006, to:

     

    i.           eliminate a Landlord's ability to levy an Above the Guideline Rent Increase for costs prescribed in subsection (1)1 relating to the municipal taxes and utilities;

     

    ii.          eliminate eligibility of capital expenditures for the purpose of an Above the Guideline Rent Increase under the categories prescribed in subsection (7) a, b and c that constitute general repair and maintenance of the property;

     

    iii.        add new subsection requiring Landlords to save 10% of rental income for a maintenance account to be accessed for capital expenditures related to the categories prescribed subsection (7) a, b and c; and

     

    iv.         no rent increases be permitted related to the enactment of i. and ii.
    Summary

    Being a renter in Toronto is becoming increasingly difficult. While guideline rent increases have been capped, Above the Guideline Increases (AGIs) for basic upkeep and repairs have pushed rents that were already steep into the unaffordable range. In addition, the low vacancy rate has made it nearly impossible to find lower-cost alternatives elsewhere. Average rents have risen $80 per month for a one bedroom in just the last four years. That's almost $1,000 a year extra at a time when wages have stagnated. No Torontonian should be forced to choose between paying rent and buying groceries, but that's the unfortunate choice too many of us are facing.

     

    An AGI is a rent increase above the "Guideline" increase that a landlord can apply for through the Landlord and Tenant Board to cover the cost of capital repairs such as replacing elevators or balconies. As a result of this provincial law, tenants are being unfairly burdened for the landlord’s cost of doing business. Landlords already receive guideline increases and further rent hikes from vacancy decontrol to deal with their costs. Repairs should be included as part of a landlord's overall expenses and paid for from the significant rent they already receive.

     

    This Motion requests the Province to amend the Residential Tenancies Act to require that landlords maintain the building and pay for maintenance as needed, not be given incentive to let their buildings deteriorate and then place huge bills on the backs of tenants. This Motion also requests that landlords be required to save 10% of rental income for a maintenance account that they can then access for capital expenditures instead of getting tenants to fund the projects. A similar requirement is already in place for condominiums.

     

    (Submitted to City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014 as Member Motion MM48.19)
    Background Information
    Member Motion MM48.19
    (http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-66923.pdf)

    Motion Without Notice
    MM48.20

    ACTION 

     

     

    Ward:28 
    545-565 Sherbourne Street Zoning Amendment and Rental Housing Demolition and Conversion Application - Revision to Final Recommendations in TE10.6 - by Councillor Pam McConnell, seconded by Councillor Kristyn Wong-Tam
    * Notice of this Motion has not been given. A two-thirds vote is required to waive notice.
    * This Motion is subject to referral to the Toronto and East York Community Council. A two-thirds vote is required to waive referral.
    * This Motion has been deemed urgent by the Chair.

    Bill 122 has been submitted on this Item.
    Recommendations

    Councillor Pam McConnell, seconded by Councillor Kristyn Wong-Tam recommends that:

     

    1.          Item TE10.6 be amended by deleting Part 4:

     

    4.         Before introducing the necessary Bills to City Council for enactment, City Council require the applicant to enter into a Site Plan Agreement under Section 41(16) of the Planning Act and Section 114 of the City of Toronto Act to the satisfaction of the Chief Planner and Executive Director and the City Solicitor.
    Summary

    City Council adopted Item TE10.6 on October 24, 2011, approving the Recommendations contained in the 545-565 Sherbourne Street – Zoning Amendment and Rental Housing Demolition and Conversion Application Final Report, Application No. 08 231178 STE 28 OZ and 08 231183 STE 28 RH, dated September 13, 2011 from the Director, Community Planning, Toronto and East York District.

     

    Included in the Recommendations was a requirement that the applicant enter into a Site Plan Agreement prior to the introduction of Bills to Council for enactment. The applicant has been working with City Staff and are approaching the conclusion of the site plan approval process.

     

    This Motion recommends deleting Part 4 of Item TE10.6 which requires the applicant to enter into a Site Plan Agreement prior to the introduction of Bills to Council for enactment. This Motion is urgent as the Bills are before Council at this meeting for approval.

     

    City Planning staff have no objections to this amendment.

     

    (Submitted to City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014 as MM48.20)
    Background Information
    Member Motion MM48.20
    (http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67062.pdf)

    Motion without Notice
    MM48.21

    ACTION 

     

     

    Ward:27 
    625, 629 and 637 Yonge Street and 1, 3, 5, 7 and 9 Isabella Street - Zoning Amendment Application - Request for Directions Report - by Councillor Kristyn Wong-Tam, seconded by Councillor Pam McConnell
    * Notice of this Motion has not been given. A two-thirds vote is required to waive notice.
    * This Motion is subject to referral to the Toronto and East York Community Council. A two-thirds vote is required to waive referral.
    * This Motion has been deemed urgent by the Chair.
    Recommendations

    Councillor Kristyn Wong-Tam, seconded by Councillor Pam McConnell, recommends that:

     

    1.         City Council adopt the following recommendations contained in the report (February 7, 2014) from the Chief Planner and Executive Director, City Planning:

     

    1.         City Council request the Director of Community Planning, Toronto and East York District bring a Directions Report on the Zoning By-law Amendment application for 625, 629 and 637 Yonge Street and 1, 3, 5, 7 and 9 Isabella Street (File: 12 260124 STE 27 OZ) to a Toronto and East York Community Council in 2014.

     

    2.         City Council request the Director of Community Planning, Toronto and East York District initiate an amendment to the Official Plan to create a "site and area specific policy" for the block bounded by Yonge Street to the west, Isabella Street to the north, Gloucester Street to the south, and Gloucester Lane to the east, generally stating that the block contain a maximum of two tall buildings, with a minimum separation of 25 metres between the face of the tall building towers; and, that the amendment be scheduled for consideration at the same Toronto and East York Community Council as the revised Zoning By-law Amendment application for 625, 629 and 637 Yonge Street and 1, 3, 5, 7 and 9 Isabella Street.

     

    3.         Staff be directed to schedule a community consultation meeting for the proposed Official Plan amendment with the Ward Councillor.

     

    4.         Notice for the community consultation meeting be given to landowners and residents within 120 metres of the site.

     

    5.         Notice for the public meeting under the Planning Act be given according to the regulations under the Planning Act.

     
    Summary

    The applicant has referred Zoning By-law Amendment application for 625, 629 and 637 Yonge Street and 1, 3, 5, 7 and 9 Isabella Street to the Ontario Municipal Board due to Council's failure to make a decision on the application within the time prescribed by the Planning Act.  A pre-hearing conference was held on November 18, 2013 and a further pre-hearing is scheduled for February 19, 2014.  A hearing date is scheduled for July 14 to July 25, 2014.

     

    The application referred to the Ontario Municipal Board was to permit a mixed-use development consisting of a 40-storey building, including a 4-storey base building, with a density of 20 times the lot area.

     

    At its meeting on December 16, 17 and 18, 2013, City Council requested that the Chief Planner and Executive Director, City Planning, to report directly to the February 19 and 20, 2014 meeting of City Council (CC45.8).

     

    The applicant advised that a revised application is to be submitted to the City for review which will require the application to be referred back to Toronto and East York Community Council for further consideration.

     

    City staff are also requesting direction from City Council to explore the potential for an amendment to the Official Plan to create a "site and area specific policy" for the block bounded by Yonge Street to the west, Isabella Street to the north, Gloucester Street to the south, and Gloucester Lane to the east.  The proposed amendment would generally state that the block would contain a maximum of two tall buildings, with a minimum separation of 25 metres between the face of the tall building towers.

     

    (Submitted to City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014 as MM48.21)
    Background Information
    Member Motion MM48.21
    (http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67064.pdf)
    (February 7, 2014) Report from the Chief Planner and Executive Director, City Planning on 625, 629 and 37 Yonge Street and 1, 3, 5, 7 and 9 Isabella Street - Zoning Amendment Application
    (http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67065.pdf)

    Motion Without Notice
    MM48.22

    ACTION 

     

     

    Ward:All 
    Council Members? 2014 Salary Increase - by Mayor Rob Ford, seconded by Councillor Doug Ford
    * Notice of this Motion has not been given. A two-thirds vote is required to waive notice.
    * This Motion is subject to referral to the Executive Committee. A two-thirds vote is required to waive referral.
    * This Motion has been deemed urgent by the Chair.
    Recommendations

    Mayor Rob Ford, seconded by Councillor Doug Ford, recommends that:

     

    1.         City Council request Members of Council to donate to the City an amount equivalent to their salary increase for the balance of the 2014 Council term.
    Summary

    Members’ compensation is governed by the provisions of City of Toronto Municipal Code Chapter 223.  Members' salaries are increased annually on January 1st by the increase in Statistics Canada’s Toronto Consumer Price Index, as calculated by the Deputy City Manager and Chief Financial Officer and based on the previous year’s average.

     

    Members of Council should set the example and forgo their salary increase for the balance of the 2014 Council term in order to demonstrate a commitment to controlling expenditures.

     

    Council should consider this matter as soon as possible in order to maximize the resulting financial benefits.

     

    (Submitted to City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014 as MM48.22)
    Background Information
    Member Motion MM48.22
    (http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67063.pdf)
    (February 20, 2014) Fiscal Impact Statement from the Deputy City Manager and Chief Financial Officer
    (http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67100.pdf)

    Motion Without Notice
    MM48.23

    ACTION 

     

     

    Ward:5 
    Request to Accept a Donation from the Maple Leafs Sports and Entertainment Foundation for Upgrades to Central Arena - by Councillor Peter Milczyn, seconded by Councillor Sarah Doucette
    * Notice of this Motion has not been given. A two-thirds vote is required to waive notice.
    * This Motion is subject to referral to the Executive Committee. A two-thirds vote is required to waive referral.
    * This Motion has been deemed urgent by the Chair.
    Recommendations

    Councillor Peter Milczyn, seconded by Councillor Sarah Doucette, recommends that:

     

     1.        City Council authorize the General Manager, Parks, Forestry and Recreation to accept the donation from the Maple Leaf Sports and Entertainment Foundation in the amount of $50,000 for upgrades to Central Arena in accordance with the Policy on Donations to the City of Toronto for Community Benefits.

     

    2.         City Council amend the 2014 Operating Budget for Parks, Forestry and Recreation by $50,000 gross and $0 net.
    Summary

    Maple Leaf Sports and Entertainment Foundation has been an integral part in improving the City of Toronto's recreational infrastructure. Over the past seven years, since its inception, the partnership has supported over 33 facility refurbishments.

     

    Maple Leafs Sports and Entertainment (MLSE) and its Toronto Marlies hockey team will be hosting a practice at Central Arena, Etobicoke on Thursday, February 20, 2014.  In recognition of this event, the MLSE Foundation would like to donate $50,000 to the City of Toronto for upgrades to Central Arena which will benefit the user groups of the facility.

     

    The donation would be applied to such items as the replacement of safety netting around rink, a new scoreboard, extension of player benches, installation of a water bottle fill station and improvements the lobby washrooms.   

     

    The urgency of this Motion requires Council to approve the acceptance of this financial donation for the cheque presentation at 7:00 pm on February 20, 2014 at Central Arena.

     

    According to the Policy on Donations to the City for Community Benefits, Sections 3.8 and 3.9, where the proposed donation is $50,000 or more, Council approval is required to accept a donation where the donation is designated for specific purposes.

     

    (Submitted to City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014 as MM48.23)
    Background Information
    Member Motion MM 48.23
    (http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67061.pdf)

    Motion without Notice
    MM48.24

    ACTION 

     

     

    Ward:30 
    Extending the Ice Skating Season on Monarch Park Rink - by Councillor Paula Fletcher, seconded by Councillor John Filion
    * This Motion has been deemed urgent by the Chair.
    * This Motion is not subject to a vote to waive referral. This Motion has been added to the agenda and is before Council for debate.
    Recommendations

    Councillor Paula Fletcher, seconded by Councillor John Filion, recommends that:

     

    1.         City Council request the General Manager, Parks, Forestry and Recreation to keep the artificial ice rink at Monarch Park in operation up to and including the March Break, weather and budget permitting.
    Summary

    The Artificial Ice Rink at Monarch Park is a popular neighbourhood hub and home to a growing women's shinny group. With the cold weather poised to continue into March, a number of residents have requested the operation of the rink be extended until the end of March Break.

     

    The City of Toronto has made efforts to re-engage the communities who use our parks and recreation facilities, and to respond to the needs of the community when feasible. In this case, the community is requesting that all efforts be made to extend the skating season in Monarch Park.

    Motion without Notice
    MM48.25

    ACTION 

     

     

    Ward:32 
    1880-1882 Queen Street East - Request for Direction on OMB Hearing- by Councillor Mary-Margaret McMahon, seconded by Councillor Adam Vaughan
    * This Motion has been deemed urgent by the Chair.
    * This Motion is not subject to a vote to waive referral. This Motion has been added to the agenda and is before Council for debate.
    Confidential Attachment - The receiving of advice that is subject to solicitor-client privilege and litigation or potential litigation, including matters before administrative tribunals, affecting the municipality or local board
    Recommendations

    Councillor Mary-Margaret McMahon, seconded by Councillor Adam Vaughan, recommends that:

     

    1.         City Council adopt the following recommendations contained in the report (February 14, 2014) from the City Solicitor:

     

    1.         That City Council adopt the recommendations contained in the Confidential Attachment 1 to the report (February 14, 2014) from the City Solicitor.

     

    2.         That the recommendations contained in the Confidential Attachment 1 to the report (February 14, 2014) from the City Solicitor and the information contained in Appendix "A" be made public at such time as City Council adopts the recommendations.  All other information contained in the Confidential Attachment 1 is to remain confidential.
    Summary

    At its meeting of May 7, 8, 9 and 10, 2013, City Council adopted Toronto East York Community Council Item 23.16 entitled "Request for Direction Report - 1880 and 1882 Queen Street East and 196 Woodbine Avenue - Zoning Amendment Application." 

     

    The staff report recommended opposing the proposal because it was inconsistent with the planning vision for the area.  

     

    This Motion is brought forward on an urgent basis as a two week hearing is scheduled to commence on February 24, 2014.  Additional information has been received and staff require Council's instructions.

     

    (Submitted to City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014 as MM48.25)

    OMB Hearing - 35 Auto Mall Drive - Official Plan Amendment, Zoning By-law Amendment and Draft Plan of Subdivision - by Councillor Raymond Cho, seconded by Councillor Ron Moeser
    * This Motion has been deemed urgent by the Chair.
    * This Motion is not subject to a vote to waive referral. This Motion has been added to the agenda and is before Council for debate.
    Recommendations

    Councillor Raymond Cho, seconded by Councillor Ron Moeser, recommends that:

     

    1.         City Council adopt the following recommendations in the report (February 14, 2014) from the City Solicitor:

     

    1.         authorize the City Solicitor and other appropriate City staff to attend at the Ontario Municipal Board in support of the official plan amendment, zoning by-law amendment and subdivision applications to permit a large-scale, stand-alone retail use, along with ancillary retail uses, including a gas station at 35 Auto Mall Drive.
    Summary

    On March 22, 2012, Planning and Growth Management Committee adopted a preliminary report from the Chief Planner and Executive Director, City Planning (the "Chief Planner" entitled "35 Auto Mall Drive - Official Plan Amendment, Zoning By-law Amendment and Draft Plan of Subdivision Applications - Preliminary Report."  The report set out a number of issues that would need to be resolved in order for staff to recommend approval of the applications.  The proposal is to develop a portion of the lands with one large-scale stand-alone retail use as well as ancillary retail uses, including a gas station.

     

    Additional reports and studies as well as revisions to those already submitted have been provided by the applicant to address concerns raised by City staff.

     

    This Motion is brought forward on an urgent basis because a further pre-hearing meeting of this matter is scheduled for March 21, 2014 and it is necessary to give instructions to City staff to proceed and to prepare for this Ontario Municipal Board hearing.

     

    (Submitted to City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014 as MM48.26)

    Ward:24 
    Potential Relocation from 251 Esther Shiner Boulevard - Oriole Yard - by Councillor David Shiner, seconded by Councillor Peter Leon
    * This Motion has been deemed urgent by the Chair.
    * This Motion is subject to a re-opening of Item EX35.18. A two-thirds vote is required to re-open that Item. If re-opened, the previous Council decision remains in force unless Council decides otherwise.
    Recommendations

    Councillor David Shiner, seconded by Councillor Peter Leon, recommends that:

     

    1.         City Council amend its November 13, 14, 15 and 18, 2013 decision on Item EX35.18 by rescinding the request that staff report to the Executive Committee and instead requesting the Director, Real Estate Services, in consultation with the General Manager, Transportation Services and the Acting General Manager, Parks, Forestry and Recreation to report to the Government Management Committee in May 2014 with respect to recommendations and operational impacts of the relocation from Oriole Yard, as per the Yard Property Utilization Initiative adopted by City Council on November 27, 2012.
    Summary

    On November 13, 2013, City Council adopted item EX35.18, which directed the General Manger, Transportation Services and the General Manager, Parks, Forestry and Recreation, to report to the Executive Committee on their progress and operational impacts of the relocation from Oriole Yard (located at 251 Esther Shiner Boulevard).  This recommendation came from a motion that was introduced at Executive Committee on October 30, 2013.

     

    Real Estate Services is currently in consultation with Transportation Services, Forestry Services, and Parks Services to examine potential relocation options for Oriole Yard.  However, total relocation costs and operational impacts have not been determined at this time.

     

    It is my request that City Council delegate to Government Management Committee the responsibility of this matter, as it is real estate related and falls within Government Management Committee's mandate.  It is my recommendation that staff report to the Government Management Committee in May 2014 with further information. 

     

    The original motion called for this item to be considered at the February meeting of Executive Committee, however, in consultation with City staff, it was suggested that this matter should be considered at the upcoming Government Management Committee held on May 12, 2014.  In order to meet the agenda timetable requirements for the May meeting of Government Management Committee, it is important that this is considered now.


     

    REQUIRES RE-OPENING:

     

    Item EX35.18 adopted by City Council on November 13, 14, 15 and 18, 2013, only as it pertains to the request for staff to report to the Executive Committee.

     

    (Submitted to City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014 as MM48.27)

    Member Motion MM48.27

    MM48.28

    ACTION 

     

     

    Ward:23 
    Staff Representation at an Ontario Municipal Board Hearing for 142 Cameron Avenue - by Councillor John Filion, seconded by Councillor Joe Mihevc
    * This Motion has been deemed urgent by the Chair.
    * This Motion is not subject to a vote to waive referral. This Motion has been added to the agenda and is before Council for debate.
    Recommendations

    Councillor John Filion, seconded by Councillor Joe Mihevc, recommends that:

     

     1.        City Council authorize the City Solicitor to appeal the approval of the minor variances for 142 Cameron Avenue, and authorize the City Solicitor to attend the Ontario Municipal Board hearing in opposition to the Committee of Adjustment's approval of the minor variances with respect to the front yard setback and the building height.

     
    Summary

     On January 22, 2014, the Committee of Adjustment North Panel considered an application for Minor Variances submitted by Rubinoff Design Group, on behalf of the owners, to permit the construction of a new two-storey dwelling at 142 Cameron Avenue. The application included a proposed front yard setback of 7.0 metres, where 10.05 metres is required, and a proposed building height of 10.28 metres, where 10.0 metres is allowed. At the hearing on January 22, the Committee approved the application.

     

    Under the recently implement Zoning By-law, the requirement for front yard setback on a lot positioned between two lots of differing front yard setbacks is taken by averaging the front yard setbacks of the two abutting lots. This ensures a smooth transition between homes, and protects the abutting neighbours from unreasonable loss of privacy, daylight and enjoyment of their properties. The variance allowing a front yard setback of 7.0 metres where 10.05 metres is required does not meet this need. In addition, the variance allowed for building height does not fit the character of the neighbourhood or meet the standards of the Zoning By-law, standards which were reinforced in the Zoning By-law recently implemented by Council.

     

    In order to meet the appeal deadline, City legal Staff have already appealed the decision pending confirmation of this action by City Council. It is therefore urgent that this matter be dealt with at this Council meeting.

     

    (Submitted to City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014 as MM48.28)
    Background Information
    Member Motion MM48.28
    (http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67043.pdf)
    Notice of Decision (Minor Variance/Permission) for 142 Cameron Avenue
    (http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67075.pdf)

    Motion without Notice
    MM48.29

    ACTION 

     

     

    Ward:20 
    231-237 College and 177-189 Huron Street - Technical Amendment to By-law No. 1675-2013 - by Councillor Adam Vaughan, seconded by Councillor Joe Mihevc
    * This Motion has been deemed urgent by the Chair.
    * This Motion is not subject to a vote to waive referral. This Motion has been added to the agenda and is before Council for debate.

    Bill 131 has been submitted on this Item.
    Recommendations

    Councillor Adam Vaughan, seconded by Councillor Joe Mihevc, recommends that:

     

    1.         City Council amend By-law 1675-2013 by replacing the text for subsection 1(e) in the by-law with the revised text attached to this Motion.

     

    2.         City Council direct the City Solicitor to bring forward to Council’s meeting of March 20, 2014 for enactment by Council, a by-law to make the changes to By-law 1675-2013 noted in Recommendation 1 above; and

     

    3.         City Council determine through the adoption of this recommendation that, pursuant to Section 34(17) of the Planning Act, no further notice is to be given in respect of the changes to By-law 1675-2013.
    Summary

    At its meeting held on December 16, 17 and 18, 2013 City Council adopted the recommendations of Planning and Growth Management Committee Item PG 29.1 for technical amendments to City of Toronto Zoning By-law 569-2013.  At the same meeting, City Council enacted By-law 1675-2013, which implemented the recommendations by removing specific properties from the By-law that meet the criteria of the Transition Protocol and correcting other errors and omissions.  Subsection 1(e) of By-law 1675-2013 removed 233 College Street from By-law 569-2013.  By-law 1675-2013 has been appealed to the Ontario Municipal Board. 

     

    It has come to City Planning's attention that the address listed in the text for subsection 1(e) of By-law 1675-2013 must be revised to include all the addresses for this site.  The mapping of Schedule 5 in the By-law is correct.  The recommended text change will ensure that subsection 1(e) corresponds  with the area shown on Schedule 5.  It is therefore appropriate that the technical amendments as set out in Item PG 29.1 be made to By-law No. 569-2013 without the need for any further public notice.

     

    This is an urgent matter since the City-wide City of Toronto Zoning By-law was enacted almost a year ago and further delay may cause hardship to the property owner.

     

    (Submitted to City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014 as MM48.29)
    Background Information
    Member Motion MM48.29

    Amending the Composition of the Toronto Music Industry Advisory Council - by Councillor Michael Thompson, seconded by Councillor Shelley Carroll
    * This Motion has been deemed urgent by the Chair.
    * This Motion is subject to a re-opening of Item ED27.2. A two-thirds vote is required to re-open that Item.
    * If re-opened, the previous Council decision remains in force unless Council decides otherwise.
    Recommendations

    Councillor Michael Thompson, seconded by Councillor Shelley Carroll, recommends that:

     

    1.         City Council increase the composition of the Toronto Music Industry Advisory Council by one additional Councillor at-large, so that the composition will now be up to 35 Members, including two (2) Councillors at-large.
    Summary

    City Council at its December 16, 17 and 18, 2013 meeting, adopted as amended, Item ED27.2 and established the Toronto Music Industry Advisory Council.  The Advisory Council's composition is up to 34 members, including a Member of Council at-large, to be appointed on the recommendation of the Striking Committee.

     

    The Striking Committee's recommendation to appoint a Councillor at-large is before City Council at this meeting as Item ST13.2.

     

    In recognition of the tremendous interest in the Toronto Music Industry, Council would benefit from the addition of another Councillor at-large position on the Advisory Council.

     

    This matter is urgent as the appointment of Council Members is before the February 19 and 20, 2014 Council meeting.

     

    Requires Re-opening

     

    Item ED27.2 headed "Toronto Music Sector (Collaborating for Competitiveness - Implementation Action 6)", adopted by City Council on December 16, 17 and 18, 2013, only as it pertains to the number of Council Member at-large positions on the Toronto Music Industry Advisory Council, in order to consider increasing the composition.

    ACTION 

     

     

    Ward:All 
    Chief Executive Officer Search - Hummingbird (Sony) Centre for the Performing Arts - by Councillor Paula Fletcher, seconded by Councillor Pam McConnell
    * This Motion has been deemed urgent by the Chair.
    * This Motion is not subject to a vote to waive referral. This Motion has been added to the agenda and is before Council for debate.
    Communication MM48.31.1 has been submitted on this Item
    Recommendations

    Councillor Paula Fletcher, seconded by Councillor Pam McConnell, recommends that:

     

    1.         City Council request the Hummingbird (Sony) Centre for the Performing Arts Board of Directors, during its search process for and appointment of a new Chief Executive Officer, to:

     

    a.         ensure that candidates for the Chief Executive Officer position are informed that the Theatres Working Group will explore closer working relationships between the three civic theatres, including the potential for a shared vision, and make recommendations to the City on the mandates of the theatres, as set out in the motion adopted by each of the three theatre boards in October 2013 [EX36.6, December 2013];

     

    b.         ensure that candidates for the Chief Executive Officer position are informed that the City, with the Theatres Working Group and external advisors, is undertaking a study to recommend options for future governance and potential operating models for the theatres [EX36.6 December 2013]; and

     

    c.         ensure that the appointment of a new Chief Executive Officer is made on the basis of a short-term or flexible employment contract that meets the objectives of the City and the Hummingbird (Sony) Centre for the Performing Arts Board of Directors.

     

    2.         City Council request the Chair of the Board of Directors of the Hummingbird (Sony) Centre for the Performing Arts to provide, through the City Manager, confidential information to City Council setting out the Chief Executive Officer selection process undertaken and conclusions reached by the Board prior to the Board finalizing its selection of a candidate for the position of Chief Executive Officer, and to attend the meeting of City Council at which the report will be considered.

     

    3.         City Council direct the City Solicitor to provide appropriate support to the Chair of the Board and to the Board of Directors of the Hummingbird (Sony) Centre for the Performing Arts in the preparation of offers of employment and employment contracts arising from the Board’s Chief Executive Officer selection process. 
    Summary

    The Chief Executive Officer of the Hummingbird (Sony) Centre for the Performing Arts has announced his retirement and the Board of Directors has commenced a search process to find a replacement.

     

    The Board should ensure that appropriate management is in place while also recognizing the importance of coordinating and aligning with the Theatres Working Group and the Theatres study initiatives and the need to maintain maximum flexibility.  

     

    This Motion is urgent as the search for a new Chief Executive Officer is already underway.

     

    (Submitted to City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014 as Member Motion MM48.31)

    Summary

    Recent events in Ukraine have seen the tragic loss of life and countless injuries through civil unrest. 

     

    Toronto is a City that is founded on democratic principles that promote inclusiveness, transparency and good government.  We must continue to promote our values by displaying a commitment to our beliefs. 

     

    (Submitted to City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014 as MM48.32)
