    Motion without Notice
    MM48.33

    ACTION 

     

     

    Ward:All 
    Revisions to Rush Hour Stopping/Standing/Parking Offences - Clarifying Regulations and Enforcement - by Councillor Denzil Minnan-Wong, seconded by Councillor Josh Matlow
    * This Motion has been deemed urgent by the Chair.
    * This Motion is not subject to a vote to waive referral. This Motion has been added to the agenda and is before Council for debate.

    Bill 130 has been submitted on this Item.
    Recommendations

    Councillor Minnan-Wong, seconded by Councillor Matlow, recommends that:

     

    1.         City Council approve the removal of rush hour offences as they apply to "No Parking" during rush hour periods, as follows: 

     

    a.         by amending Subsection 950-101B.1 in Municipal Code Chapter 950, Traffic and Parking, to delete the phrase: "950-405A.1," with respect to the definition of the term "RUSH HOUR PERIOD" as it applies to "No parking during rush hour times.";

     

    b.         by amending Municipal Code Chapter 950, Traffic and Parking, to delete Subsection 950-405A.1, "No parking during rush hour times."; and

     

    c.         by amending Municipal Code Chapter 950, Traffic and Parking, to delete from the table to Subsection 950-1201A, the table of fixed fines for stopping, standing or parking offences, reference to Subsection 950-405A.1 ("No parking during rush hour times.") and the associated $150.00 fine.

     

    2.         City Council, to clarify "No Stopping" offences during rush hour periods, amend Subsection 950-405D.1, "No stopping during rush hour times", by inserting the phrase: "where the hours as set out under Column four (Prohibited Times and/or Days) in Schedule XIV begin, end and are contained entirely within the time period of 6:00 a.m. to 10:00 a.m. and/or the time period of  3:00 p.m. to 7:00 p.m. of the rush hour period" after the phrase "under Column four (Prohibited Times and/or Days) in Schedule XIV".

     

    3.         City Council, to clarify "No Standing" offences during rush hour periods, amend Subsection 950-405G.1, "No standing during rush hour times", by inserting the phrase: "where the hours as set out under Column four (Prohibited Times and/or Days) in Schedule XVI begin, end and are contained entirely within the time period of 6:00 a.m. to 10:00 a.m. and./or the time period of 3:00 p.m. to 7:00 p.m. of the rush hour period" after the phrase "under Column four (Prohibited Times and/or Days) in Schedule XVI".

     

    4.         City Council direct the City Solicitor to submit the necessary bills to make such by-law amendments, including those necessary to make amendments to City of Toronto Municipal Code Chapter 903, Parking for Persons with Disabilities, if required, as may be required to give effect to Council's decision. 
    Summary

    City Council, at its meeting on February 6 and 7, 2012, adopted, as amended, Public Works and Infrastructure Committee Item 11.2 entitled "Relieving Rush Hour Congestion Due to Unlawful Stopping, Standing, and Parking" and, in so doing, adopted an increased fixed and set fine of $150.00 for stopping/standing/parking offences during rush hour periods.  By-law Nos. 165-2012 and 166-2012 were enacted in connection with this Item.

     

    The increased rush hour stopping/standing/parking offences and associated fines came into force on January 23, 2014. With implementation, two issues have come to light:

     

    1.         Applying peak-hour fines to "No Parking" locations is not consistent with the intent of Council; and

    2.         Interpretation of the defined rush hour periods.

     

    The increased fine for rush hour offences was intended to improve traffic flow during peak periods by acting as a deterrent to illegal stopping and standing on main roads.   "No Parking" prohibitions permit motorists to legally stop for short durations while actively engaged in loading and unloading passengers and/or merchandise.  Since a "No Parking" prohibition permits temporary stopping, it is not used in situations where a lane is intended to be clear for travel.  On streets where maintaining a clear lane for traffic flow is imperative, the City implements "No Stopping" or "No Standing" prohibitions.  As such, it is recommended that Council eliminate the "No parking during rush hour times" offence and the associated fine of $150.00.

     

    Secondly, Transportation Services identified a need to clarify how the rush hour period is defined to ensure fair and consistent enforcement.  Transportation Services, in consultation with the Toronto Police Service, Parking Enforcement, determined that in keeping with the intent of Council's decision in Public Works and Infrastructure Committee Item 11.2, the "No stopping during rush hour times" offence and the "No standing during rush hour times" offence be clarified to identify that these rush hour period offences will apply where the time periods in the associated schedule for the offences clearly begin, end and are contained entirely within the defined rush hour period times.

     

    This Motion is urgent as the current by-law is resulting in parking tickets being issued at rush hour rates ($150.00) in locations that would not be considered rush hour routes.  Immediate clarification of by-law language is required to ensure greater consistency and facilitate enforcement.

     

    (Submitted to City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014 as Member Motion MM48.33)
    Background Information
    Member Motion MM48.33
    (http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67080.pdf)

    Motion without Notice
    MM48.34

    ACTION 

     

     

    Ward:24 
    Acquisition of Lands to Complete East/West Road between Rean Drive and Kenaston Gardens - Southeast Bayview Node Context Plan - by Councillor David Shiner, seconded by Councillor Peter Leon
    * This Motion has been deemed urgent by the Chair.
    * This Motion is not subject to a vote to waive referral. This Motion has been added to the agenda and is before Council for debate.
    Recommendations

    Councillor David Shiner, seconded by Councillor Peter Leon, recommends that:

     

    1.         City Council request the Director of Real Estate Services, in consultation with the Director of Transportation Services, North York District, the Director of Community Planning, North York District, and the City Solicitor, to identify the land acquisitions necessary to complete the east/west road shown on Map 4 of the Southeast Bayview Node Context Plan, running from Rean Drive to Kenaston Gardens, and to report to Government Management Committee with respect to the means by which those lands may be acquired by the City and the potential cost and source of funds to complete the acquisitions.
    Summary

    City Council at its meeting on February 29, March 1 and 2, 2000 (Report No. 3 of North York Community Council, Clause 23) adopted the Southeast Bayview Node Context Plan, which is a set of urban design guidelines to provide a framework for development in the south-east quadrant of the intersection of Sheppard Avenue East and Bayview Avenue, including potential development blocks created by existing and new streets.  Map 4 (Transportation Options) to the Context Plan illustrates potential new roads in the area, including a new east/west road running from Rean Drive to Kenaston Gardens.  Over the years, a large portion of that new road has been constructed as a result of adjoining development applications.

     

    The purpose of this Motion is to direct City staff to report to Government Management Committee on the identification of the land acquisitions necessary to complete the road and the means by which those lands may be acquired.


    Neighbouring properties along this new roadway are subject to an appeal at the Ontario Municipal Board.  In order for City staff to be able to report to the April 7, 2014 meeting of the Government Management Committee, it is necessary that City Council give consideration of this report request at today's meeting.

     

    (Submitted to City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014 as Member Motion MM48.34)
    Background Information
    Member Motion MM48.34
    (http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67079.pdf)

    Motion without Notice
    MM48.35

    ACTION 

     

     

    Ward:23 
    Revision to the Zoning By-law Amendment for the Property at 49 Hendon Avenue, 26 and 28 Greenview Avenue and 9 to 25 Eldora Avenue - by Councillor John Filion, seconded by Councillor Joe Mihevc
    * This Motion has been deemed urgent by the Chair.
    * This Motion is not subject to a vote to waive referral. This Motion has been added to the agenda and is before Council for debate.

    Bill 132 has been submitted on this Item.
    Recommendations

    Councillor John Filion, seconded by Councillor Joe Mihevc, recommends that:

     

    1.         City Council amend Zoning By-law 1085-2013 for the lands at 49 Hendon Avenue, 26 and 28 Greenview Avenue and 9 to 25 Eldora Avenue, substantially in accordance with the revised draft Zoning By-law Amendment attached  which includes the following amendments to the Zoning By-law approved by City Council on June 11, 12, and 13 2013 (NY24.20):

     

    Subsection 2(c) be amended to read as follows: "For the purposes of this exception, "established grade" shall mean a geodetic elevation of 191.9 for Blocks A, B and C as shown on Schedule RM1(93) and a geodetic elevation of 193.25 for Blocks D and E as shown on Schedule RM1(93)."

     

    2.         City Council determine that the revisions made to the proposed zoning by-law are minor in nature and that, pursuant to subsection 34(17) of the Planning Act, no further public notice is required in respect of the proposed zoning by-law.
    Summary

     On June 11, 12, and 13 2013, City Council adopted NY24.20 authorizing the introduction of a zoning by-law for 49 Hendon Avenue, 26 and 28 Greenview Avenue and 9 to 25 Eldora Avenue to permit 10 stacked townhouse units and 103 stacked, back-to-back townhouse units (for a total of 113 units) contained within five townhouse blocks.  There are 124 underground parking spaces proposed.  The proposed height was to be a maximum of 10.7 metres and three storeys, measured from the midpoint along Eldora Avenue.  The approval by City Council was appealed by a neighbour.  However, the Ontario Municipal Board dismissed the appeal in November, 2013. 

     

    Subsequent to the statutory public meeting relating to the proposed by-laws, the applicant has requested certain modifications to the by-law related to height for two of the five townhouse blocks (Blocks D and E on Schedule RM1(93)), on the northerly portion of the site that do not conform with the height when measured from Eldora Avenue, due to the grading of the site.   Blocks A, B and C comply.  The design of the proposed townhouses has not changed since the initial approval by City Council.  The by-law requires clarification to correct an error and accommodate the height of the two northerly townhouse blocks (Blocks D and E) as they were originally intended.  

     

    City Planning and Legal advise that this item is urgent and that an amendment is required to provide clarification of the By-law.  Three of the five buildings on this site have had permits issued, and this is to facilitate the intent of the original by-law approval by Council.

     

    (Submitted to City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014 as Member Motion MM48.35)
    Background Information
    Member Motion MM48.35
    (http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67083.pdf)
    By-law to Amend the form City of North York Zoning By-law No. 7625, as amended, with respect to the Lands Municipality known as 49 Hendon Avenue, 26 and 28 Greenview Avenue and 9 to 25 Eldora Avenue
    (http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67084.pdf)

    Motion without Notice
    MM48.36

    ACTION 

     

     

    Ward:27 
    Release of Section 37 Funds, 66 Isabella Street, for Rainbow-Coloured Pedestrian Crossing Areas and Streetscape Improvements in Celebration of World Pride - by Councillor Kristyn Wong-Tam, seconded by Deputy Mayor Norman Kelly
    * This Motion has been deemed urgent by the Chair.
    * This Motion is not subject to a vote to waive referral. This Motion has been added to the agenda and is before Council for debate.
    Recommendations

    Councillor Kristyn Wong-Tam, Deputy Mayor Norman Kelly, recommends that: 

     

    1.         City Council increase the 2014 Operating Budget for Transportation Services by $50,000 gross, $0 net, fully funded by Section 37 community benefits received from the development at 66 Isabella Street, (source account: 220096), for the purpose of making the east-west pedestrian crossing areas at the Church Street/Isabella Street and Church Street/Alexander Street intersections rainbow-coloured and other identified streetscape improvements in consultation with the General Manager of Transportation Services, in celebration of World Pride.
    Summary

    Section 37 funds in the amount of $450,000 plus indexing have been secured and received in the development at 66 Isabella Street for the purposes of local streetscape and park improvements.  In celebration of World Pride, select pedestrian crossings at intersections on Church Street will be repainted in rainbow colours at a total cost of $50,000.00.

     

    This item is urgent in order for the installation to occur in time for World Pride in June 2014.

     

    (Submitted to City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014 as Member Motion MM48.36)
    Background Information
    Member Motion MM48.36
    (http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67106.pdf)

    Motion without Notice
    MM48.37

    ACTION 

     

     

    Ward:22 
    Authorization to Change the Financial Scope of Phase 8 - Casa Loma Exterior Restoration 2014-2015 Norman Tower to Accommodate Increased Costs - by Councillor Josh Matlow, seconded by Councillor Joe Mihevc
    * This Motion has been deemed urgent by the Chair.
    * This Motion is not subject to a vote to waive referral. This Motion has been added to the agenda and is before Council for debate.
    Recommendations

    Councillor Josh Matlow, seconded by Councillor Joe Mihevc, recommends that:

     

    1.         City Council approve a change of financial scope to the approved Economic Development and Culture Capital Budget for Phase 8 - Casa Loma Exterior Restoration (CAC089-11) in order to increase the 2015 cash flow by $2,012,974.00 gross/$0 net, fully funded from Casa Loma Corporation revenues.
    Summary

    The tender for Phase 8 restoration at Casa Loma closed on November 15, 2013.  This is the last phase of restoration on the main castle and includes work on the Norman Tower and the south west corner of the castle, permitting public access to the tower which has been closed for many years and facilitate the new operator's plans to establish a destination dining venue at Casa Loma.

     

    Economic Development and Culture received bids from three pre-qualified general contractors, the lowest bid was $5,792,300, excluding HST.  The architect recommended we include the separate price of $119,000 to restore the west porch.  Including the City's portion of the HST, the final total tender value is $6,012,974.36.  As the City had originally budgeted $4,101,000.00, this leaves a shortfall.

    The architect has reviewed the bid and found it to be generally good value.   Staff in Economic Development and Culture agrees with this recommendation.  At its February 18, 2014 meeting, the Casa Loma Corporation Board approved transferring an additional $2,012,974.36 from future revenue to the 2015 Culture Capital Budget for Casa Loma.

     

    It is urgent that this budget adjustment be approved so that a Purchase Order can be issued immediately and construction start by mid-spring of this year.  The estimated completion date would be end of 2015/beginning of 2016, foregoing any unforeseen delays.  This would provide the fastest timetable to release the Norman Tower, the west lawn and the west porch to the new operator so they can include these areas in their revenue generating programming. 

     

    The 2014 – 2015 approved capital budget for Casa Loma is $4,101,000 gross/$2,502,000 net including $1,599,000 from Casa Loma revenue.  We wish to accept additional funds from Casa Loma to adjust the 2015 cash flow for this previously approved project.

     

    (Submitted to City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014 as Member Motion MM48.37)
    Background Information
    Member Motion MM48.37
    (http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67108.pdf)

    Motion without Notice
    MM48.38

    ACTION 

     

     

     
    Employment Contracts regarding Senior Officials of City Agencies, Boards, Commissions and Corporations - by Councillor Michael Thompson, seconded by Councillor Peter Leon
    * This Motion has been deemed urgent by the Chair.
    * This Motion is not subject to a vote to waive referral. This Motion has been added to the agenda and is before Council for debate.
    Recommendations

    Councillor Michael Thompson, seconded by Councillor Peter Leon, recommends that:

     

    1.         City Council direct the City  Solicitor and City Manager to report to the April 23, 2014 Executive Committee meeting on the legal and policy issues regarding the public disclosure of the contracts of employment of senior officials of the City's Agencies, Boards, Commissions and Corporations. 
    Summary

    The protection of the interests of taxpayers requires an increased level of accountability and transparency for the City's Agencies, Boards, Commissions and Corporations.

     

    To this end, the public disclosure of employment contracts of senior officials would assist in increasing the level of accountability and transparency.

     

    This Motion is urgent as staff are already preparing a report for the April 2014 Executive Committee meeting and require direction now.

     

    (Submitted to City Council on February 19 and 20, 2014 as Member Motion MM48.38)
    Background Information
    Member Motion MM48.38
    (http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2014/mm/bgrd/backgroundfile-67126.pdf)

    Bills and By-laws - Meeting 48
    BL48.1

    ACTION 

     

     

    Ward:All 
    Introduction and Enactment of General Bills and Confirming Bills
    Summary

    City Council will introduce and enact general bills and confirming bills.
